thread.title: The Tesco trolley is back on track despite falling profits says chief executive
thread.title_full: The Tesco trolley is back on track despite falling profits says chief executive

title: The Tesco trolley is back on track despite falling profits says chief executive
text:
GETTY Tesco sold its Korea business for £4.2billion 
The number of transactions in its UK stores was up 1.5 per cent, while the amount of goods sold increased by 1.4 per cent. But lower prices meant sales in its UK stores open at least a year were down 1.3 per cent compared with the previous year, although the trend had improved to minus one per cent in the second quarter. 
International like-for-like sales increased in the first half for the first time in nearly three years after a recovery in Poland and Slovakia. GETTY Despite falling profits Tesco's share price has been rising 
Lewis played down concerns Tesco might tap investors for cash to rebuild its balance sheet, saying it would “stay focused on generating better returns from the assets we’ve got”. 
Despite Tesco recently selling its Korean business for £4.2billion, it will not sell its Dunhumby data business which runs its Clubcard scheme and there are no plans for further major disposals. 
It said the new national living wage would cost it £500million to increase what it pays to meet the £9-an-hour minimum by 2020. 
Bernstein analyst Bruno Monteyne said: “Stable volume market share is the key measure for Dave Lewis to enact his turnaround plan.” Shares rose 4¾p to 197p GETTY Tesco's transactions were up 1.5 per cent Related articles
